div.head: “The Constellations: Northern, Some of the Zodiac, and Some of the Southern”
MSS IA and III, RF T70
January (or January 1827?)
div.p: Undated fair copy in MS III, where title written “THE CONSTELLATIONS / NORTHERN, SOME OF THE ZODIAC AND / SOME OF THE SOUTHERN.”. Its placement after the second volume of “Harry and Lucy” and before “The Sun” suggests New Yearʼs 1828. Indeed, in the prose section of MS III preceding the poem, Harry gives Lucy a drawing of Charlesʼs Wain “as an introduction to astronomy”. Thus, Ruskinʼs editors are strictly correct in listing the poem under 1827—that is, composition in late 1827 for a New Yearʼs 1828 presentation.

The editors seem to intend earlier 1827, associating the poem with the rough draft of “The Monastery” in MS IA, which they misdate as 1827. If they based their dating on harder evidence contained in the rough draft of “Constellations” in MS IA (see Works, 2:535), their reasoning cannot be confirmed or denied, since a piece of that rough draft manuscript is now very likely missing. The evidence in MS III does hold open a possibility for an earlier date. As noted in nos. 1 and 4, Ruskin seems habitually to have included his previous yearʼs presentation poems along with the most recent New Yearʼs gift in his “Harry and Lucy” books (e.g., in MS III, Ruskin includes another older New Yearʼs poem, no. 4, in this group). Thus, “The Constellations” could have existed as a New Yearʼs gift for 1827, although no positive evidence supports the possibility.

If the poem is based on Ruskinʼs actual observation of the sky, the alignment of heavenly bodies described at the beginning of the poem would not have been possible in 1827, not even as late as December for a New Yearʼs composition. In that case, the composition would have to be moved forward to April‐May 1828, more in keeping with the occasion of John Jamesʼs birthday. See Discussion.

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: Quoted in Works, 2:260 n. 1. Previously unpublished in entirety.

A separate presentation copy of the poem is represented at the Ruskin Library by a photograph of a manuscript, taken for the Library Edition but unused (RF T70; for its physical description, see part 2, MS IA, “Contents,” b). The location of the original manuscript is unknown, as are the occasion and date of its presentation, and its physical characteristics, other than its consisting of a single folded sheet. Entitled “THE CONSTELLATIONS NORTHERN / SOME OF THE ZODIAC / AND SOME OF THE SOUTHERN”, the photograph shows a fair‐copy version predating the MS III fair copy. It runs the full length of the MS III version, but several lines are crossed out and revisions scrawled in the margins—revisions that all appear in the MS III version, excepting a word or two that were altered again for that final version. The revisions are written in an awkward longhand, unlike the tiny print lettering of the fair copy. Presumably, the RF T70 revisions were made shortly before the late 1827—early 1828 fair copy in MS III (thus, incidentally, representing one of the earliest datable examples of Ruskinʼs longhand script). In fact, the RF T70 fair copy itself, and not just its revisions, may have only shortly predated the MS III version. At line 53 of RF T70, the fair‐copy hand suddenly becomes larger and more careless, suggesting that, at this point, Ruskin decided to sacrifice this fair copy to revision (see also textual note for line 54). On the last page of the folded sheet (i.e., p. 4) in the photograph, revised lines of “The Constellations” appear to be written over top of a lighter script of lines that I am unable to connect definitely with any extant fair‐copy juvenilia: “[to(?)] heaven but / not [to(?)] hell [for when (?)] / they went to / place [I(?)] say [that then (?)] / they took quite / a different way / and . . .” (the writing continues for four more, illegible lines). The scrawled draft suggests notes for a sermon, although it might represent attempted revision of “The Constellations” since some lines were given a more pious cast in the final version (see, e.g., the textual notes for the lines “The scales in which twas vainly said / The crime and virtues of men were weighed,” and for the closing meditation on the superiority of virtue to knowledge). No surviving fair‐copy lines, however, even remotely match the faint draft.

div.head: Sources
div.p: Definitive evidence of one source of Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations is revealed in his “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, where Harry offers to “give . . . [Lucy] a drawing of charlesʼs wain as an introduction to astronomy”. The drawing, which Ruskin illustrates with his own drawing in the text, reproduces a diagram in volume 2, “Of Astronomy”, of Jeremiah Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues (2:250 opp. [pl. 1, fig. 1]). In Joyceʼs dialogue, the Tutor shows this diagram to his pupils, Charles and James, just as Ruskinʼs Harry presents the drawing to Lucy, as a first step in learning “‘how to distinguish the stars, and . . . call them by their proper names’”. He points out Charlesʼ Wain in the night sky, and illustrates the formation with the diagram—four stars forming a waggon, and three stars making the horses, all of them also forming part of a larger constellation, the Great Bear—and he explains how these constellations can serve as a compass for finding oneʼs bearings at night, without the sunʼs position to define the cardinal points. As a northern constellation, Charlesʼ Wain is always visible on a clear night; and as the diagram shows, it can be used to point to the North Star (i.e., Polaris) by tracing a line upward through the two stars forming the rear of the waggon. From this first point of reference, the Tutor proceeds to instruct Charles and James in the names and locations of other stars, constellations, and planets (coversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, Scientific Dialogues, 2:12–18).

In Ruskinʼs reading, this episode in Joyceʼs dialogues formed a node of interlocking texts, for in Maria Edgeworthʼs Frank the Engineer marks passages on astronomy in Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues where the youth can find information about astronomy. Frank himself recalls an episode in Thomas Dayʼs Sandford and Merton, in which “Harry Sandford found his way out of the moor by the help of the pole star” (Edgeworth, Frank, 2:141, 140). In Sandford and Merton, this story is told in connection with a lesson, similar to the Tutorʼs in Scientific Dialogues, in which Dayʼs tutor, Mr. Barlow, teaches Tommy to find Charlesʼs Wain as Harry did, in order to find his way on a dark night. To remember the constellations, Tommy gets the idea of diagramming the stars on paper and carries on to conceive of a celestial globe, which Mr. Barlow later provides in the form of a paper‐covered ball on which the boys record their observations of the constellations. These lessons convey practical knowledge, which saved Harryʼs life when lost on the moor, but also teach appreciation of natural beauty:

Mr. Barlow. Were there no other use, I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us. We sometimes run to see a procession of coaches, or a few people in fine clothes strutting about; we admire a large room that is painted, and ornamented, and gilded: but what is there in all these things to be compared with the sight of these luminous bodies that adorn every part of the sky?
(Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, and see 162–69, 187–88)

Ruskinʼs poem, “The Constellations”, corresponds to these methods of putting the constellations on paper. In context of Ruskinʼs own “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, the poem effectively forms Lucyʼs “introduction to astronomy”; and in the context of his reading, the poemʼs seemingly mechanical exercise of listing the star clusters carries out the method, recommended by Mr. Barlow, of “remembering these stars [in Charlesʼs Wain]” so that “you may very easily observe those which are next to them, and learn their names too, till you are acquainted with the whole face of the heavens” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 163). Just so, in Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues, the Tutor instructs Charles and James in the names and positions of the constellations.

In his poem, Ruskin adopts the tactic of Dayʼs and Joyceʼs tutors by starting from a prominent point of reference—in Ruskinʼs case, a planet, Venus, the so‐called Morning Star and Evening Star, and a wandering rather than a fixed star—and he carries on to list the formations more or less in sequence, as do Tommy and Harry on their globe. Joyceʼs Tutor leads his pupils on a somewhat more complicated path, starting from the diagram of Charlesʼs Wain and proceeding to a celestial globe, but moving rapidly to orient the constellations to the ecliptic and equator, and then teaching them to consult an ephemeris or almanac of the longitudes and latitudes, times of rising and setting, and other information about the heavenly bodies (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, “Of Astronomy”, conversations 2–4, 2:12–47).

div.head: Real-life Observations
div.p: Ruskin possibly built his simpler catalogue of constellations based on actual observation of Venus, just as Joyce initially situates his fictional characters observing the evening sky at the end of a lingering walk. According to a digital‐age ephemeris, Venus would have been visible from London as an evening star, setting in the west and appearing close to Orionʼs belt, in April‐May 1828. Mars would not have been visible high in the sky precisely at that time, but would have risen from the east somewhat later, after Venus had set. This particular configuration of planets and constellations would not have appeared at any other time in 1828, and not at all in 1827. During those two months in 1828—the time when Ruskin would have been composing poetry for his fatherʼs birthday—the northern constellations could be viewed circling counter‐clockwise overhead, in roughly the sequence listed in the poem—Ursa Major (the Great Bear), Draco (the Dragon), Corona Borealis (the Crown), Coma Berenices (Bereniceʼs Hair). Beyond this point in Ruskinʼs list, the sequence is jumbled compared to what one would have seen in the sky, having to dart in different directions to find Cygnus (the Swan); Charlesʼs Heart, which is a star in Canes Venatici (Hunting Dogs); and so on (Sky & Telescope, Interactive Star Chart and Celestial Almanac, accessed 20 March 2022). Of course, if based on any actual observation at all, Ruskinʼs poem reflect experience mixed with information gleaned from a book or globe.

A distinct difference between Ruskinʼs poem and Joyceʼs dialogue is that Ruskin is interested in the poetic images evoked by the mythic names, whereas Joyceʼs Tutor and his scholars are dismissive of what they regard as largely humbug: “James. ‘Why are the signs of the Zodiac called by the several names of Aries, Taurus, Leo, &c. I see no likeness in the heavens to Rams, or Bulls, or Lions, which are the English words for those Latin ones’. Tutor. ‘Nor do I’” (conversation 4, “Of the Ephemeris”, Scientific Dialogues, 2:36–37).

One lesson that Joyceʼs Tutor dwells on is the arbitrariness underlying the naming systems of astronomy. The imagined patterns in the sky, whereby the Greek ordered and named the constellations, were arbitrary constructions. As the Tutor emphasizes: “‘The ancients, that they might the better distinguish and describe the stars, with regard to their situation in the heavens, divided them into constellations, that is, systems of stars, each system consisting of such stars as were near to each other, giving them the names of such men or things, as they fancied the space which they occupied in the heavens represented’”. Charles takes the point: it is “perfectly arbitrary, that one collection is called the great bear, another the dragon; a third Hercules, and so on” (conversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, in Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, 2:13–14). The arbitrariness of naming extends beyond the ancient constellations to modern systems: “‘If you look on the [celestial] globe’”, the Tutor continues, “‘you will observe, that . . . [lesser stars] are distinguished by the different letters of the Greek alphabet’”, which are also assigned arbitrarily (conversation 3, “Of the Fixed Stars, and Ecliptic”, Scientific Dialogues, 2:23).
